title: Pattern of a Lifeline
creator: Maddy Casey
description: In this project, creator Maddy Casey explores the theme of inheritance by converting data about the lives and interests of three generations of women in her family into a prototype-sized skirt. The under-layer is a crinoline made of wire- the degree to which the wire extends from the skirt corresponds to emotionally difficult life experiences. The top layer maps each persons’ interests and hobbies over the course of their lives using different colored ribbon. The data for the project was collected through personal reflection and conversation, and the materials and techniques used are fabric, jewelry-grade wire, and sewing.
subject: data art; data physicalization; Genealogy--Data processing; Sewing in art; Personal Identity
location: 300 Fraser Purchase Rd, Latrobe, PA 15650
source: Summer Data Physicalization Class, Pratt School of Information
rights: In Copyright- Educational Use Permitted

title: NYC’s Tree Canopy Inequality
creator: Alison Long
description: In this project, creator Alison Long expresses data about the unequal distribution of a tree canopy across New York City's five boroughs through a sculpture made of stretched fabric. The project uses data from the 2015 NYC tree census and population data from the 2020 U.S. census.  The scale of each piece of fabric represents the proportion of the city's tree canopy that covers each corresponding borough.
subject: data art; data physicalization; Trees in cities; Climate justice; Sustainable urban development
location: 144 W 14th St 6th floor, New York, NY 10011
source: Summer Data Physicalization Class, Pratt School of Information

title: The Clam: Physicalization of Endometriosis
creator: Alison Long
description: In this project, creator Alison Long converted data from a survey about endometriosis, a chronic health condition in which tissue similar to the uterine lining grows outside the uterus, into a sculptural piece made of multi-colored foam clay.  The project expresses information about the lived experience of endometriosis, which includes severe pain, fatigue, and emotional distress, through a tactile representation of the survey data.  The data's position on the interior of the smooth, sculpted, shell, is reflective of the invisible nature of endometriosis to outsiders.  The survey data used can be found here: Oehmke, F., Weyand, J., Hackethal, A., Konrad, L., Omwandho, C., & Tinneberg, H. R. (2009). Impact of endometriosis on quality of life: a pilot study. Gynecological endocrinology : the official journal of the International Society of Gynecological Endocrinology, 25(11), 722–725. https://doi.org/10.3109/09513590903159607.
subject: data art; data physicalization; endometriosis; gender-affirming care; reproductive health
location: 144 W 14th St 6th floor, New York, NY 10011
source: Summer Data Physicalization Class, Pratt School of Information
rights: This license enables reusers to distribute, remix, adapt, and build upon the material in any medium or format, so long as attribution is given to the creator. title: Earth Crust Relics Library: the Void
creator: Nene Villalobos
description: For this piece, creator Nene Villalobos expressed data about the ecological and social impact of large Amazon warehouses on a local community in the Inland Empire through a sculptural piece made of bristol board.
subject: data art; data physicalization; Climate justice; Express highways; Warehouses--Conservation and restoration
location: Ontario, CA, Intersection of I-10 and I-15
source: Summer Data Physicalization Class, Pratt School of Information

title: Queer Data Portraits
creator: Morgan King
description: For this piece, creator Morgan King converted personal data about their close friends into data portraits. The project encodes information about each person through colorful fabrics and embroidery, to explore themes of queer identity and connection.
subject: data art; data physicalization; LGBTQ+ chosen families; Friendships; Personal Identity
location: 144 W 14th St 6th floor, New York, NY 10011
source: Summer Data Physicalization Class, Pratt School of Information
rights: In Copyright- Educational Use Permitted

source: Summer Data Physicalization Class, Pratt School of Information
rights: In Copyright- Educational Use Permitted
image_alt_text: A rectangular piece of turquoise fabric with sewn on pieces of light blue, yellow, and patterned fabric (the last ressembles the surface of the moon). A photograph of a person sitting at a piano, and a small photo of a waterfall are tucked into a pocket on the piece. Curving lines of decorative  yellow and green embroidery adorn the piece. Small pieces of fabric are tacked onto the piece- a pisces symbol, orange and red outlines of human figures, a yellow circle, and a red circle. An orange photo of a child in nature and a sparkling ocean are attached to the center of the piece.
